1.rationale:
My position at (4,8) is near the top center of a 10x10 board, with the nearest apples scattered: (4,0) directly below but far, (1,3), (2,4), and (0,6) clustered to the left-bottom, and (8,6) to the right-middle. The enemy snake is at (2,9), far enough to not immediately threaten, but I must avoid potential head-on collisions—remembering that if our heads end up in the same cell this turn or this turn, both die. No bodies yet, so no self-collision risks, and all four directions (UP, DOWN, LEFT, RIGHT) are on-board and body-free, making them all immediately safe without obvious lethal traps. However, the game favors moves increasing access to apples safely while keeping future options open (e.g., avoiding corners or bottlenecks). Board state shows wide open space, with no tight areas nearby, so flexibility is high. Prioritizing: moving LEFT brings me toward the left-side apples ((1,3), (2,4), (0,6)) in a direction with more board room to maneuver, versus RIGHT (potential toward (8,6) but crossing toward a wall edge) or UP/DOWN (minimal apple proximity benefit and UP is already near board edge). If the enemy moves DOWN to (2,8) or LEFT to (1,9), no shared spaces; if RIGHT to (3,9), still no collision with me left at (3,8). This keeps multiple future safe moves (up, down, left, perhaps even looping back right safely) while positioning for growth.

**Future strategy note: Move east/west to flank apple clusters while staying spaced from the enemy—prioritize heading down after repositioning to avoid top-board crowding, aiming for (4,0) or left-bottom cluster, then loop for safety entour if needed.**
